Justification: It isn't that I think GE food is always, across-the-board worse. I think this is an issue with a great deal more nuance, and it's frustrating that it's constantly being framed as, "If you oppose Monsanto, you're an evil person who wants starving people to die of preventable famines and malnutrition." The example of the disease-resistant bananas is one of GE being used for good, and I have no problem with that. The problem I have is that most of the GE food on the US market (where I personally live) is made by Monsanto to be more tolerant not to disease, but to Round-Up. Which means more Round-Up on the crops, which I DO think is bad for human health. It's also kind of, GE sometimes solves problems the hard way rather than the easy way--a lot of the vulnerability to crop disease can be handled via diversity of strains of crop, rather than the monocultures we grow now. And Monsanto has tried to put growers of heritage strains of crops out of business by charging them with copyright violations if any seed of theirs blows into the wind onto the other farmer's field, even though that farmer was likely trying NOT to grow Monsanto's crops. Additionally, a lot of the hunger in the world is due to distribution problems in capitalism and wealth inequality, not in there literally being an absence of food on planet Earth. We waste more than enough food to feed everyone who's hungry. So GE sometimes solves a problem that isn't quite the problem we actually had, and then that kind of gets used as apologia for Monsanto's BS.
